questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of hereditary hemochromatosis is being evaluated for his condition. Which of the following is considered the most important but nonspecific regulator of iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hepcidin

 

Option A:

 

Hepcidin is considered the most important but nonspecific regulator of iron metabolism. It's synthesized in the liver and plays a central role in systemic iron homeostasis. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. DMT1 (Divalent metal transporter 1) is a specific transporter that moves ferrous iron across the apical membrane of enterocytes. While important for iron uptake, it has a more focused role.

 

Option C. Ferroportin is the protein responsible for exporting iron from cells into the plasma. It has a specific function and is regulated by hepcidin.

 

Option D. Ferritin is the primary intracellular iron storage protein and is a marker of iron stores but does not regulate iron metabolism directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepcidin is the most important but nonspecific regulator of iron metabolism since it not only controls iron homeostasis but also has broader effects including antimicrobial activity and is influenced by various physiological and pathological conditions.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 652

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with acrocyanosis and hemolysis after exposure to cold temperatures. His direct Coombs' test is positive with cold sub type of antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgM

 

Option C:

 

  • Clinical presentation given in the stem of the question is suggestive of Cold Agglutinin disease.
  • Cold hemagglutinin is associated with IgM antibodies. These are not to be confused with anti-IgM antibodies given as other option in the question. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Anti-IgM would imply an antibody against IgM itself, which is not the cause of cold hemagglutinin disease. Cold agglutinins are typically IgM antibodies that can agglutinate and lyse red blood cells at cold temperatures.

 

Option B.  Anti-IgG suggests an antibody against IgG, which is not typically involved in cold hemagglutinin disease. IgG antibodies can, however, cause warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

 

Option D. Donath-Landsteiner antibody: The Donath-Landsteiner antibody is seen in paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria..

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cold agglutinin disease is characterised by IgM antibodies whereas PCH is characterised by Donath-Landsteiner (IgG antibodies against P-antigen on RBC surface) 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 649-50

choices.text: Hemolytic uremic syndrome

questions.text: A child presents with acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia after a diarrheal illness. A peripheral blood smear shows fragmented red cells, including helmet cells. Which condition is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hemolytic uremic syndrome

Option A:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) often follows a diarrheal illness caused by certain strains of E. coli. It is characterized by the triad of acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes, including helmet cells on peripheral smear.

Explanation:

Option B. Polysplenia is a condition where multiple small spleens are present and is typically associated with congenital abnormalities; it does not characteristically present with schistocytes or helmet cells.

Option C. Spherocytosis is a disorder causing spherically shaped red blood cells due to a defect in the RBC membrane, not typically associated with schistocytes or helmet cells.

Option D. Acanthocytosis refers to spur cells with spiculated membranes, which are seen in liver disease and abetalipoproteinemia, among others, and does not present with helmet cells.

Educational Objective:

Helmet cells on a blood smear are characteristic of microangiopathic hemolytic anemias, such as those seen in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which can present with renal failure and thrombocytopenia following gastroenteritis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 662

choices.text: Thalassemia major
Thalassemia minor
Iron deficiency anemia​
Anemia of chronic disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with the following laboratory values: hemoglobin 9gm%, MCV is 55%, RBC is 4.5 million/mm3. There is no history of blood transfusion. What is the most likely diagnosis out of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thalassemia minor

  Option B:

Thalassemia major patient presents with severe anemia and cannot survive without blood transfusion, so this option can be easily ruled out. For other options, Mentzer index is useful for differentiating between thalassemia minor and iron deficiency anemia.

  Thalassemia minor often presents with mild to moderate anemia and a low MCV. The Mentzer index, calculated as MCV divided by the RBC count, is less than 13 in thalassemia minor.

Explanation:

Option A. Patients with thalassemia major typically present with severe anemia requiring regular blood transfusions. The degree of anemia in the vignette is not consistent with thalassemia major.

Option C. Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic and hypochromic anemia. The Mentzer index is generally greater than 13, which is not the case here.

Option D. Anemia of chronic disease usually presents with normocytic or sometimes microcytic anemia, but it is often characterized by a normal or increased storage iron level, which can be evaluated by serum ferritin.

Educational Objective:

When presented with mild to moderate microcytic anemia and an MCV/RBC count that yields a Mentzer index of less than 13, thalassemia minor is a likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Beta thalassemia trait
Sickle cell anemia
G6 PD deficiency

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with mild anemia noted on routine screening. She reports a family history of anemia but has no significant personal medical history. She denies any symptoms of anemia. A hemoglobin electrophoresis is performed, showing an increased HbA2 level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta thalassemia trait

 

Option A:

 

Beta thalassemia trait is characterized by a mutation in the beta-globin gene, leading to reduced (β+) or absent (β0) production of β-globin chains. Compensatory increase in HbA2 (α2δ2) is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Hemoglobin electrophoresis usually reveals an increase in HbA2 (α2δ2) to 4% to 8% of the total hemoglobin (nor¬mal, 2.5% ± 0.3%), which is a reflection of an elevated ra¬tio of δ-chain to β-chain synthesis. HbF levels are generally normal or occasionally slightly increased

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sickle cell anemia is characterized by a mutation in the beta-globin gene that leads to the production of hemoglobin S. Hemoglobin electrophoresis in sickle cell anemia typically shows a predominance of HbS and possibly elevated HbF but not HbA2.

 

Option C. Hereditary spherocytosis is a disorder of the red blood cell membrane leading to spherical erythrocytes and hemolytic anemia. It does not involve abnormalities in hemoglobin synthesis or elevated HbA2 levels.

 

Option D. G6PD deficiency is an X-linked enzymatic defect leading to hemolytic anemia under conditions of oxidative stress. It is not associated with an increase in HbA2 on electrophoresis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals increased HbA2 levels, it is indicative of beta thalassemia trait, reflecting an imbalance in globin chain production.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 641

choices.text: Acute myeloid leukemia
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

questions.text: A peripheral smear with increased neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils, and platelets is highly suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Chronic myelogenous leukemia

Option C:

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML): is characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting in the constitutive activation of the BCR-ABL1 tyrosine kinase. This leads to increased production of myeloid cells, including neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils, and platelets. The peripheral smear in CML often shows a "left-shift," with increased mature and immature myeloid cells.

Explanation:

Option A: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): is characterized by the rapid growth of abnormal myeloid cells in the bone marrow. While AML may show increased myeloid cells in the peripheral smear, it typically presents with blasts and a decrease in mature cells, unlike the broad spectrum of increased cells seen in the question.

Option B: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL): primarily affects lymphoid cells. It is characterized by the presence of lymphoblasts in the peripheral blood. The question describes an increase in myeloid cell lineages (neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils, and platelets), making ALL less likely.

Option D: Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): is a group of disorders characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis. While MDS can present with cytopenias and dysplastic changes in blood cells, the specific pattern described in the question (increased neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils, and platelets) is more indicative of CML.

Educational objective:

Chronic myeloid leukemia is a stem cell disease that is characterized by leukocytosis with granulocytic immaturities, basophilia, splenomegaly and distinct chromosomal abnormality Philadelphia chromosome.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 622)

questions.text: A patient presents with acrocyanosis and hemolytic anemia after exposure to cold weather. Laboratory tests reveal agglutination of red blood cells at temperatures between 4 to 6°C. Which type of immunoglobulin is most likely responsible for this agglutination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IgM

Option B:

Cold agglutinins are monoclonal IgM antibodies that react at 4 to 6°C. They are called agglutinins because the IgM directed against the ‘I’ antigen present on the RBCs can agglutinate red cells due to its large size (pentamer).

IgM antibodies are known as cold agglutinins and are the primary antibodies involved in cold agglutinin disease. They have a pentameric structure that allows them to effectively bridge and agglutinate red blood cells.

Explanation:

Option A. IgG antibodies are generally involved in warm autoimmune hemolytic anemias and do not typically cause agglutination at low temperatures.

Option C. IgA antibodies are mainly secretory antibodies and do not usually cause agglutination of red blood cells in cold environments.

Option D. IgD antibodies are found in very low concentrations in serum and are not associated with cold agglutination of red blood cells.

Educational Objective:

IgM antibodies, known as cold agglutinins, can cause agglutination of red blood cells at low temperatures, as seen in cold agglutinin disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 648

choices.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoim­mune haemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm auto­immune haemolytic anemia
RBC lysis due to hemoglobinopathy
Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated cold autoim­mune haemolytic anemia​​​​​​

questions.text: A 56-year‑old female presents in the month of December with chronic fatigue and cyanosis of nose with blue lips. A peripheral blood smear showed the following image. What is the most likely cause of the findings seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune haemolytic anemia

Option A:

The image shows agglutinated red cells. Since the his¬tory mentions that cyanosis is seen affecting fingers and tips of nose in the month of December, it suggests that the red cells agglutinated with cold antibody associated autoimmune haemolytic anemia.

Cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia (CAHA) is caused by IgM antibodies that agglutinate red blood cells at low temperatures. This typically happens in the cooler peripheral parts of the body and can lead to symptoms like cyanosis when the patient is exposed to cold environments. The condition can cause chronic fatigue due to anemia resulting from the destruction of agglutinated red blood cells.

   Explanation:

Option B. Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (WAIHA) involves IgG antibodies that react with red blood cells at body temperature, leading to their destruction by the spleen. This would not typically be associated with cold exposure and is not consistent with the symptom of cyanosis, which is related to cold.

Option C. Hemoglobinopathies, such as sickle cell disease, can cause hemolytic anemia, but the red blood cells do not clump in response to cold. Instead, hemoglobinopathies typically involve structural abnormalities of the hemoglobin molecule itself.

Option D. Cold agglutinin disease can sometimes involve IgG antibodies, but it is more commonly associated with IgM antibodies. IgG-mediated hemolysis at cold temperatures is much less common and would not explain the typical clumping seen in CAHA.

Educational Objective:

It is important to recognize the clinical and laboratory findings consistent with cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia (CAHA), where IgM antibodies bind to red blood cells at low temperatures, causing them to agglutinate. This can lead to hemolytic anemia, resulting in symptoms such as chronic fatigue and cyanosis upon cold exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 643-4

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely to be a pre-leukaemic condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paroxysmal cold haemoglobinuria

Option C:

PCH (paroxysmal cold hemoglobinu­ria) is an autoimmune haemolytic anemia due to IgG autoanti­bodies which bind to P blood group antigen and cause intravascu­lar hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and have recovery within a month.

Explanation:

Option A: “PNH: about 5% to 10% of patients eventually develop acute myeloid leukemia or a my­elodysplastic syndrome, possibly because hematopoietic stem cells have suffered some type of genetic damage’.

Option B:  Aplastic anemia results from a fundamental stem cell defect supported by the presence of karyotypic aberrations in many cases; the occasional trans­formation of aplasia into myeloid neoplasms, typically myelodysplasia or acute myeloid leukemia; and the asso­ciation with abnormally short telomeres.

Option D: The term “myelodysplastic syndrome” (MDS) refers to a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects that are associated with ineffective hematopoiesis and a high risk of transformation to AML.

Educational objective:

Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH) is primarily an autoimmune hemolytic anemia and not commonly associated with transformation to leukemia, which makes it the least likely condition to be pre-leukemic.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 545)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with dark urine in the morning and has been found to have hemolytic anemia on laboratory evaluation. A diagnostic test reveals increased sensitivity of his red blood cells to lysis in acidified serum. Which of the following underlying defects is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Defective GPI anchor

 

Option C:

 

Ham’s acidified serum test is used for the diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). In this condition, defective GPI anchor prevents the attachment of CD55, CD59 and C8 binding protein.

 

A defective GPI (glycosylphosphatidylinositol) anchor leads to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) by failing to secure protective proteins such as CD55 and CD59 to the cell membrane, leaving red blood cells susceptible to complement-mediated lysis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spectrin is a cytoskeletal protein that helps maintain the red blood cell's shape. Defects in spectrin can cause hereditary spherocytosis but are not associated with increased red cell lysis in acidified serum.

 

Option B. Defect in complement activating proteins: PNH is due to complement regulatory (inhibitory) proteins not because of complement activating proteins.

 

Option D. The Mannose-binding lectin pathway is involved in innate immunity and can lead to opsonization and phagocytosis of pathogens, but defects here do not lead to the clinical picture described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A defective GPI anchor is implicated in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a condition that can be diagnosed with the Ham test, indicating increased red blood cell lysis in acidified serum due to increased complement sensitivity.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 645

questions.text: Myelofibrosis leading to a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is seen with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute megakaryocytic leukemia

 

Option C:

 

Acute megakaryocytic leukemia is a subtype of AML characterized by the proliferation of megakaryocytic precursors. This condition can lead to fibrosis in the bone marrow. As a consequence, a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration may occur due to the increased fibrous tissue. Therefore, this option is associated with myelofibrosis and a dry tap.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Burkitt’s lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that primarily involves B cells. It typically presents with rapidly growing tumors, often in the jaw or abdomen. Bone marrow involvement in Burkitt's lymphoma is uncommon. While bone marrow examination may reveal lymphoma cells, it is not typically associated with myelofibrosis, and a dry tap is not a characteristic finding.

 

Option B: Acute erythroblastic leukemia (erythroleukemia) is a rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by the proliferation of immature erythroid precursors. This condition can infiltrate the bone marrow, leading to a hypercellular marrow with an excess of erythroid precursors. Myelofibrosis and dry tap are not typical features of acute erythroblastic leukemia.

 

Option D: Acute undifferentiated leukemia refers to a subtype of acute leukemia in which the blasts (immature cells) in the bone marrow lack specific features that would allow classification into myeloid or lymphoid lineages. While acute leukemias can sometimes be associated with bone marrow fibrosis, the dry tap is not typically a defining feature of this subtype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute megakaryocytic leukemia, a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the proliferation of megakaryocytic precursors, is associated with the development of myelofibrosis within the bone marrow, which can lead to a 'dry tap' during bone marrow aspiration due to increased fibrous tissue.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: An elderly female with mediastinal mass undergoes a microscopic examination showing red cell aplasia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Thymoma

Option B:

The description of an elderly female with a mediastinal mass and microscopic examination showing red cell aplasia is suggestive of a thymoma. Thymomas are tumors arising from the thymic epithelial cells in the thymus, which is located in the mediastinum. Thymomas can be associated with various paraneoplastic syndromes, and one of them is pure red cell aplasia. Direct lines from Robbins. “In addition to myasthenia gravis, thymomas may be associated with several other paraneoplastic syndromes. These include in rough order of frequency, pure red cell aplasia, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi organ autoimmunity”.

Thymoma is a tumor of the thymic epithelial cells and can present as a mediastinal mass. It is associated with several paraneoplastic syndromes including pure red cell aplasia, which leads to severe anemia due to the failure of the bone marrow to produce red blood cells, myasthenia gravis, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi-organ autoimmunity.

Explanation:

Option A. Bronchogenic cancer often presents as a mediastinal mass, especially in smokers. However, it is not commonly associated with red cell aplasia, but rather with other paraneoplastic syndromes such as hypercalcemia (due to production of PTH-related protein) or the secretion of ADH or ACTH.

Option C. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can present as a mediastinal mass. It may cause bone marrow involvement leading to various cytopenias but is not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma typically arises from the epithelial cells of the skin or mucous membranes and is not commonly found within the mediastinum. It is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, but not typically with red cell aplasia.

Educational Objective:

Thymoma is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with a mediastinal mass and red cell aplasia, as thymomas are associated with this condition and other paraneoplastic syndromes such as myasthenia gravis, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi-organ autoimmunity.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p493

questions.text: A 12-year-old with history of recurrent infection and bleeding gums. On investigations the patient had pancytopenia and the peripheral smear showed macrocytes. The bone marrow biopsy showed no megakaryocytes and filled with fat globules. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Aplastic anemia

Option B:

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation of a 12-year-old with recurrent infections, bleeding gums, pancytopenia, macrocytes on peripheral smear, absence of megakaryocytes in bone marrow, and the presence of fat globules in the bone marrow biopsy is suggestive of aplastic anemia. Aplastic anemia is characterized by a deficiency of all blood cell types (pancytopenia) due to bone marrow failure. The absence of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow biopsy indicates a lack of platelet precursors, which can lead to bleeding manifestations. The presence of fat globules suggests replacement of hematopoietic cells by adipose tissue in the bone marrow.

EXPLANATION:

Option A. Myelodysplastic syndromes :may also present with cytopenias and dysplastic changes in the bone marrow, but the absence of megakaryocytes and the presence of fat globules are not typical features.

Option C. ITP: is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia without affecting other cell lines. It does not typically present with pancytopenia or the absence of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow.

Option D. PNH:  is characterized by hemolysis, often presenting with hemoglobinuria. However, it is not typically associated with pancytopenia and fat globules in the bone marrow.

Educational Objective:

The clinical presentation of recurrent infections, bleeding gums, pancytopenia, macrocytes on peripheral smear, absence of megakaryocytes in bone marrow, and presence of fat globules in bone marrow biopsy is indicative of aplastic anemia. This diagnosis is supported by the bone marrow biopsy findings showing a lack of megakaryocytes, indicative of platelet precursor deficiency, and fat globules suggesting the replacement of hematopoietic cells by adipose tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/458

choices.text: It uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach and infect B cells
It is implicated in B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed people
It is a potent inducer of B-cell growth and transformation
EBV infection always results in Burkitt lymphoma

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy. Serological tests are positive for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. Which of the following statements about the pathophysiology of EBV is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) EBV infection always results in Burkitt lymphoma

Option D:

EBV infection always leads to the development of Burkitt lymphoma. This is incorrect. While EBV is associated with Burkitt lymphoma, not everyone infected with EBV will develop this type of lymphoma. The association is strong in endemic areas, but the majority of EBV infections result in infectious mononucleosis or are asymptomatic.

Explanation:

Option A. It uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach and infect B cells. This is correct. EBV uses the CD21 receptor, which is the complement receptor on B cells, to infect them.

Option B. It is implicated in B-cell lymphomas in individuals with immunosuppression. True. EBV is associated with various B-cell lymphomas, especially in individuals who are immunosuppressed, such as those with HIV or post-transplant patients.

Option C. It is a potent inducer of B-cell growth and transformation. This is correct. EBV can drive B-cell growth and transformation, contributing to the development of diseases like infectious mononucleosis and, in some cases, B-cell lymphomas.

Educational Objective:

EBV infection does not always lead to Burkitt lymphoma. While EBV can infect B cells and is associated with various lymphomas, the outcome of infection ranges from asymptomatic to infectious mononucleosis, with only a minority progressing to Burkitt lymphoma or other types of B-cell lymphoma.


Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 326

choices.text: Increased reticulocyte count

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with fatigue, light-headedness, and a beefy-red tongue. Laboratory tests show macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following laboratory findings is inconsistent with untreated megaloblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increased reticulocyte count

Option A:

An increased reticulocyte count is not a feature of untreated megaloblastic anemia. In megaloblastic anemia, the reticulocyte count is typically low because of ineffective erythropoiesis. However, the count increases once treatment with vitamin B12 and folate is initiated, reflecting a response to treatment.

Explanation:

Option B. Raised bilirubin levels can be seen in megaloblastic anemia due to increased destruction of defective erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow, which release bilirubin into the blood.

Option C. Mild splenomegaly may be observed in megaloblastic anemia as the spleen works to filter the abnormal cells from the bloodstream.

Option D. The presence of nucleated RBCs in the peripheral blood smear is a sign of severe anemia, including megaloblastic anemia, where immature and abnormal erythroid precursor cells are released into the bloodstream.

Educational Objective:

in untreated megaloblastic anemia, the reticulocyte count is low due to impaired DNA synthesis and ineffective erythropoiesis. An increased reticulocyte count after initiating treatment with vitamin B12 and folate supplementation indicates a positive response to therapy.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 645, Wintrobe’s 12th/1151-3

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with jaundice and anemia. His blood smear shows spherical red blood cells, and laboratory tests reveal an increase in mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Hereditary spherocytosis

 

Option D:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the red blood cell membrane, leading to a spherical or spheroid shape. Due to the loss of membrane surface area, the concentration of hemoglobin within the smaller, more compacted cells is increased, resulting in an elevated MCHC.

 

Elevated MCHC is a characteristic feature of spherocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: It is characterized by a decrease in the amount of hemoglobin in red blood cells, leading to a decreased MCHC.

 

Option B. Megaloblastic anemia: It can be associated with vitamin B12 or folate deficiency and has macrocytosis. This condition is associated with a normal or decreased MCHC.

 

Option C. Anemia of chronic disease: The anomie is often normocytic and normochromic, with a normal MCH

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis often presents with an elevated MCHC due to the spherical shape of red blood cells, which concentrates the haemoglobin content

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 639

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with anemia and abdominal pain. On examination, he has pigmented macules over the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Further investigations reveal loss-of-function mutations of the STK11 gene. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jeghers syndrome

Option D:

  • The given scenario is suggestive of Peutz Jeghers syndrome. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder due to loss of function mutations of STK11.
  • It is associated with arborizing polyps of the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine > colon > stomach).
  • It increases the risk of multiple epithelial cancers, particularly of colon, breast, lung, pancreas, and thyroid.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by the development of benign polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and distinctive mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. It is caused by mutations in the STK11 gene, which increase the risk of several epithelial cancers.

Explanation:

Option A. HNPCC: HNPCC, also known as Lynch syndrome, is an autosomal dominant condition predisposing individuals to early-onset colorectal cancer and other malignancies. It is associated with mutations in mismatch repair genes, not STK11.

Option B. Gorlin syndrome: Gorlin syndrome, or nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome, is characterized by multiple basal cell carcinomas, odontogenic keratocysts, and skeletal anomalies. It is associated with mutations in the PTCH1 gene, not STK11.

Option C. Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is a hereditary cancer syndrome associated with a variety of tumors, including hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It is related to mutations in the VHL gene.

Educational Objective:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with gastrointestinal polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation, due to mutations in the STK11 gene, and it elevates the risk of multiple cancers.

choices.text: Serum ferritin is decreased
Reduced hepcidin levels
Transferrin saturation is decreased
Total iron binding capacity is increased​​​​​

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and pallor. Her blood tests show mild anemia. Additional laboratory tests are ordered to determine the cause of her anemia. Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with a diagnosis of anemia of chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transferrin saturation is decreased

Option C:

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD), also known as anemia of inflammation, is a type of anemia that occurs in the setting of chronic inflammatory conditions, infections, or malignancies. It is characterized by disturbances in iron metabolism. The correct laboratory findings for the diagnosis of anemia of chronic disease are:

Transferrin saturation is decreased in anemia of chronic disease due to limited availability of iron for erythropoiesis, even though iron stores are often adequate.

  • Increased hepcidin levels
  • Transferrin saturation is decreased:
  •  Serum ferritin is increased
  • Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) is decreased

Explanation:

Option A.  In iron deficiency anemia, serum ferritin, which reflects body iron stores, is decreased.

Option B. Hepcidin levels are typically increased in anemia of chronic disease because it is an inflammatory marker that blocks the release of iron from body stores, contributing to the anemia.

Option D. In anemia of chronic disease, TIBC is usually normal or decreased, not increased, because the body's iron is sequestered due to inflammation and is not readily available for erythropoiesis.

Educational Objective:

In anemia of chronic disease, transferrin saturation is decreased due to limited iron utilization, despite adequate or increased iron stores reflected by normal or increased serum ferritin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p658

choices.text: Deletion of 4 alpha chains
Deletion of 3 alpha chains
Deletion of 2 alpha chains
Deletion of 1 alpha chain

questions.text: HbH is formed due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deletion of 3 alpha chains

Option B:

Deletion of 3 alpha chains leads to the formation of HbH disease. HbH is composed of four beta-globin chains and is formed in response to the lack of sufficient alpha chains.

Explanation:

Option A. Deletion of all 4 alpha chains typically results in hydrops fetalis and is usually incompatible with life; hence it does not lead to the formation of HbH.

Option D. Deletion of 1 alpha chain usually causes no significant clinical symptoms and is known as silent carrier state; it does not lead to HbH formation.

Option C: Deletion of 2 alpha chains often causes a milder form of alpha thalassemia, known as alpha thalassemia trait or alpha thalassemia minor, not typically associated with the formation of HbH.

Educational Objective:

HbH disease is caused by the deletion of three alpha-globin genes, which leads to an excess of beta-globin chains that form the abnormal hemoglobin H (beta4).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 645

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a clinical presentation feature of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Leukemia

 

Option B:

 

The triad of pancytopenia, thrombosis and hemolytic anemia is characteristic of PNH.

 

Aplastic anemia can be a presenting feature (as per Wintrobes, Hematology). We need to remem¬ber that PNH may progress to leukemia (leukaemia CAN be a complication and NOT a feature).

 

While patients with PNH may have an increased risk of developing leukemia, it is not a defining feature of PNH but rather a potential late complication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thrombosis, particularly in unusual sites such as the hepatic or cerebral veins, is a well-recognized complication of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) due to the increased propensity for red blood cells to activate the complement system and the coagulation cascade.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia can be a presenting feature of PNH due to the associated bone marrow failure that can occur with the disease process.

 

Option D. Intravascular hemolysis is a hallmark of PNH, caused by the increased sensitivity of red blood cells to complement due to a deficiency in GPI-anchored proteins that normally protect the cell membrane from complement activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PNH is characterized by hemolytic anemia, pancytopenia, and thrombosis, but leukemia is not a feature of PNH but may be a secondary complication of the disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p648

choices.text: Blasts of acute myeloid leukemia are typically Su­dan black negative
Blasts of acute lymphoblastic leukemia are typically myeloperoxidase positive
Low leucocyte alkaline phosphatase score is charac­teristically seen in blastic phase of chronic myeloid leukemia
Tartarate resistant acid phosphatase positivity is typically seen in hairy cell leukemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements pertaining to leukemia is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tartarate resistant acid phosphatase positivity is typically seen in hairy cell leukemia

Option D:

Tartarate resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) positivity is a hallmark feature of hairy cell leukemia (HCL). This staining helps to distinguish HCL from other lymphoproliferative disorders and is positive in the majority of HCL cases.

Explanation:

Option A: Blasts in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) are often Sudan black positive. This histochemical stain is used to detect the presence of myeloid granules in blasts, which are typically abundant in AML cells.

Option B: Blasts of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) are generally myeloperoxidase (MPO) negative. MPO is an enzyme found predominantly in myeloid cells and is used as a marker to distinguish AML (where blasts are typically MPO positive) from ALL.

Option C: A low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is seen in the chronic phase of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), reflecting the abundance of immature leukocytes. However, the LAP score often increases when CML progresses to the blast crisis phase, due to the presence of a higher proportion of mature leukocytes.

Educational Objective:

Tartarate resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) positivity is typically seen in hairy cell leukemia (HCL), which is useful for its diagnosis and differentiation from other hematologic disorders.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 604)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Laboratory investigations reveal a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Peripheral blood smear shows microcytic red blood cells, and bone marrow biopsy confirms the presence of ringed sideroblasts. The patient does not have a history of significant alcohol consumption. Which of the following treatments is most likely to improve the anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pyridoxine

Option C:

Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia characterized by the presence of ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow. It can be either inherited (genetic) or acquired. Acquired sideroblastic anemia is often associated with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and can respond to treatment with pyridoxine (vitamin B6).

Pyridoxine is a cofactor for the enzyme ALA synthase, which is involved in heme synthesis. Pyridoxine-responsive anemias, including some sideroblastic anemias, can show improvement with vitamin B6 supplementation.

Explanation:

Option A. iron supplementation is used for iron deficiency anemia, which typically does not feature ringed sideroblasts. In sideroblastic anemia, there is usually adequate or increased iron in the body, but it's not properly incorporated into hemoglobin.

Option B.Thiamine deficiency does not typically cause sideroblastic anemia, so supplementation would not address the underlying pathophysiology in this case.

Option D. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia, not typically sideroblastic anemia, so this would not be the treatment of choice for a patient with ringed sideroblasts.

Educational Objective:

Sideroblastic anemia can be responsive to pyridoxine supplementation, especially when ringed sideroblasts are observed on bone marrow biopsy and the patient does not have a history of conditions that could cause secondary sideroblastic anemia, such as alcoholism or lead poisoning.

questions.text: A physician is considering the differential diagnoses for a patient's elevated serum tumor marker levels. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is known to be elevated in various malignancies and benign conditions. Which of the following conditions is NOT typically associated with an elevated CEA level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoma prostate

Option C:

Prostate specific antigen (PSA) is elevated in carcinoma prostate

Carcinoma of the prostate CEA is not a marker for prostate cancer. Instead, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the commonly used tumor marker for diagnosing and monitoring prostate cancer.

Explanation:

Option A. Alcoholic cirrhosis Alcoholic cirrhosis can lead to elevated CEA levels. CEA is not specific for malignancy and can be raised in a variety of benign liver conditions, including cirrhosis, especially when related to alcohol use.

Option B. Carcinoma of the colon CEA levels are frequently elevated in colorectal cancer and can be used as a marker for monitoring treatment response or disease recurrence after the removal of the primary tumor.

Option D. Emphysema Chronic lung conditions, including emphysema, can also result in elevated CEA levels, even though these are not malignant conditions. Smoking, which is a risk factor for emphysema, can itself cause elevated CEA levels.

Educational Objective:

Carcinoma of the prostate, is not associated with elevated CEA levels. Instead, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the tumor marker commonly elevated in prostate cancer. CEA is used primarily for monitoring colorectal cancer and can be elevated in various benign conditions, including liver and lung diseases.

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 336

choices.text: Folic acid deficiency

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. Laboratory investigations reveal macrocytic anemia, and the FIGLU test is conducted to assess the etiology. FIGLU test is done for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folic acid deficiency

Option B:

Folate deficiency can also cause macrocytic anemia. An elevated urinary FIGLU (formiminoglutamic acid) test indicates an inability to metabolize FIGLU due to insufficient folate, which is needed for its conversion to glutamic acid

Explanation:

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to macrocytic anemia and is usually confirmed by low serum levels of B12 or elevated serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels, not typically with a FIGLU test.

Option C. Deficiency of thiamine leads to conditions like beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not typically associated with macrocytic anemia or a positive FIGLU test.

Option D. Riboflavin deficiency is associated with symptoms such as angular stomatitis and glossitis, but not usually with macrocytic anemia, and it does not cause elevated FIGLU levels.

Educational Objective:

In patients with unexplained macrocytic anemia, a positive FIGLU test in the urine indicates a deficiency in folate. FIGLU is a biomarker for intracellular levels of folate.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a malignancy that is associated with an overexpression of the c-Myc gene. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this overexpression?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gene amplification

Option A:

Gene amplification results in multiple copies of a gene, leading to overexpression of the gene product. This mechanism is frequently responsible for the increased levels of the c-Myc protein in various cancers, as it increases the transcription of genes involved in cell growth and proliferation.

Explanation:

Option B. Chromosomal translocation: While chromosomal translocations can result in c-Myc overexpression, such as the translocation seen in Burkitt lymphoma (t(8;14), it is less common than gene amplification for the overexpression of c-Myc in a broader range of malignancies.

Option C. Point mutation: Point mutations can activate oncogenes or inactivate tumor suppressor genes, but they are not typically associated with the overexpression of c-Myc. Instead, they might alter the function of the resulting protein.

Option D. Gene deletion: Gene deletion generally leads to a loss of gene function and is more commonly associated with tumor suppressor genes rather than proto-oncogenes like c-Myc. Deletion would not result in overexpression but rather in reduced expression or loss of function.

Educational Objective:

Gene amplification is a common mechanism for overexpression of the c-Myc gene in various malignancies, leading to increased cell growth and proliferation due to the extra copies of the gene being transcribed.

  • The C-myc gene is a proto-oncogene that codes for a transcription factor involved in cell proliferation and differentiation. Overexpression of c-Myc is seen in many malignancies, and it is often due to gene amplification, which results in an increased number of copies of the gene.
  • Chromosomal translocations can also lead to c-Myc overexpression, but they are less common.

choices.text: Inhibition of PD1 receptor on T-cells
Upregulation of expression of PDL1

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms does not lead to immune evasion by the tumor cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibition of PD1 receptor on T-cells

Option A:

  • Inhibition of PD-1 receptor (Programmed death -1 receptor) on T cells causes activation of immunity against the tumor cells, not evasion.
  • PD-1 receptors present on T cells inhibit T-cell activation. This allows tumors to evade the host immunity by the upregulation of the expression of factors like PD-L1 and PD-L2, which act on PD-1 receptors.

Inhibiting the PD1 receptor on T cells actually leads to the activation of the immune response against tumor cells. This is the basis for some of the cancer immunotherapies, which block PD1 to prevent the tumor cells from evading the immune system.

Explanation:

Option B. Upregulation of expression of PDL1: Tumor cells often upregulate PD-L1, which binds to the PD1 receptor on T cells, leading to the inhibition of the immune response against the tumor, effectively allowing the tumor to evade the immune system.

Option C. Induction of galectin Tumor cells can induce galectins, which are beta-galactoside-binding proteins that can negatively regulate T-cell apoptosis, affect T-cell receptor signaling, or contribute to the creation of an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, facilitating immune evasion.

;Option D. Induction of regulatory T-cells: Tumors may induce regulatory T cells (Tregs), which suppress the activation of the immune system and maintain tolerance to self-antigens, thus aiding in tumor immune evasion.

Educational Objective:

Inhibition of the PD1 receptor on T cells does not lead to immune evasion by tumor cells; rather, it activates the immune response against the tumor. PD1 receptor inhibition is a strategy used in cancer immunotherapy to overcome tumor-induced immune suppression.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 312

choices.text: Microcytic hypochromic anemia
Sickled red cells
Anemia occurs after 3-4 years of poor absorption
Development of polycythemia

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of strict vegetarianism presents with weakness and paresthesias. A CBC shows macrocytosis, and his serum vitamin B12 level is low. Which of the following is most consistent with the pathophysiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anemia occurs after 3-4 years of poor absorption

Option C:

Because the liver stores several years' worth of vitamin B12, it can take years of inadequate dietary intake before clinical symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency anemia develop.

Explanation:

Option A. Microcytic hypochromic anemia is typically associated with iron deficiency, thalassemia, or other disorders of hemoglobin synthesis, not with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option B. Sickled red cells are characteristic of sickle cell anemia, a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the hemoglobin gene, not related to vitamin B12 absorption.

Option D. Polycythemia refers to an increased concentration of hemoglobin in the blood, typically not related to vitamin B12 deficiency. Instead, vitamin B12 deficiency would lead to a decrease in red cell production due to maturation failure.

Educational Objective:

When considering a diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, significant hepatic stores of vitamin B12 can delay the onset of anemia for several years in patients with poor dietary intake.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 651-2

choices.text: Decrease in reduced glutathione
Decrease in NADPH
Increased in lipid peroxidation
Decreased RBC membrane damage​​​

questions.text: A 30-year-old African American male presents to the emergency room with jaundice and dark urine after taking a sulfa drug for a urinary tract infection. He has a past medical history of a similar episode after eating fava beans. His labs reveal hemolytic anemia. Which of the following is NOT a consequence of the enzyme deficiency this patient most likely has?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Decreased RBC membrane damage

G6PD deficiency is associated with decrease in reduced glutathione and decreased NADPH. It is associated with increased lipid peroxidation and more RBC membrane damage.

Option D:

Decreased red blood cell membrane damage is not associated with G6PD deficiency. In fact, the lack of NADPH leads to increased oxidative stress and thus increased membrane damage, causing hemolysis.

Explanation:

Option A. In G6PD deficiency, there is a decrease in reduced glutathione due to insufficient NADPH, leading to decreased ability to neutralize oxidative stress in red blood cells.

Option B. G6PD deficiency results in a decrease in NADPH production, a critical factor in maintaining the reduced state of glutathione.

Option C. Without enough reduced glutathione, red blood cells are more susceptible to oxidative stress, leading to increased lipid peroxidation and membrane damage.

Educational Objective:

Decreased red blood cell membrane damage is not associated with G6PD deficiency.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p640

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and exertional dyspnea. Laboratory tests show a mild anemia with a hemoglobin of 10 g/dL. Further workup reveals the following: serum ferritin is elevated, total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) is decreased, serum iron is reduced, and transferrin saturation percentage is decreased. Which laboratory finding is most characteristic of the anemia of chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. S. ferritin ↑

Option D:

Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by increased serum ferritin levels, decreased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC), reduced serum iron, and a decreased percentage saturation of transferrin.

Serum ferritin is an acute-phase reactant and can be increased in anemia of chronic disease, reflecting the body's iron stores which are sequestered due to inflammatory cytokines.

Explanation:

Option A. TIBC is typically increased due to the body's attempt to increase iron binding capacity in response to low iron stores, which is not the case in anemia of chronic disease.

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease typically presents with decreased serum iron due to sequestration of iron within macrophages and hepatocytes.

Option C. In anemia of chronic disease, bone marrow iron stores are usually normal or increased, not decreased.

Educational Objective:

The most characteristic laboratory finding in anemia of chronic disease is increased serum ferritin, reflecting sequestered iron stores that are not available for effective erythropoiesis despite the body having adequate or increased total iron.

 

Robbins 10th/ 659

choices.text: Activation of cell cycle arrest

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea. CT scan reveals the presence of a tumor in the pancreas. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the KRAS proto-oncogene. Which of the following best describes the role of KRAS in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Promotion of cell proliferation

Explanation:

KRAS is a proto-oncogene that encodes for a protein involved in cell signaling pathways that regulate cell growth and division. Mutations in KRAS can lead to the activation of these pathways, promoting cell proliferation and survival. KRAS mutations are common in pancreatic adenocarcinoma and are associated with a poorer prognosis

questions.text: AML with gum infiltration and hepatosplenomegaly is most likely associated with which of the following subtypes of AML?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) M4

Option D:

(M4 - Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia): M4 subtype includes features of both myeloblastic and monocytic lineage. The monocytic component has a predilection for tissue infiltration, such as gum hypertrophy and skin involvement (leukemia cutis), making this subtype more likely to present with gum infiltration and hepatosplenomegaly.

Explanation:

Option A: (M1 - Acute Myeloblastic Leukemia without maturation): M1 subtype is characterized by a proliferation of myeloblasts without significant differentiation. While organomegaly can occur, M1 is not typically associated with gum infiltration.

Option B: (M3 - Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia): M3 subtype is unique due to its association with the t(15;17) translocation and the PML-RARA fusion gene. It can present with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but gum infiltration is less characteristic of M3.

Option C: (M2 - Acute Myeloblastic Leukemia with maturation): M2 subtype shows some degree of myeloid maturation. It can occasionally involve extramedullary sites, but gum infiltration and hepatosplenomegaly are more typical of AML with monocytic differentiation, such as M4 and M5.

Educational Objective:

Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia (M4) is commonly associated with extramedullary manifestations such as gum infiltration and hepatosplenomegaly due to the infiltrative nature of the monocytic component of the leukemia.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 618)

questions.text: What is affected in sickled hemoglobin; HbS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Solubility

Option D:

Solubility is the property most affected by the mutation causing HbS. Under deoxygenated conditions, HbS polymerizes, leading to the formation of insoluble fibers that deform the red blood cells into a sickle shape.

Explanation:

Option A. Stability refers to the hemoglobin molecule's resistance to denaturation and degradation. While HbS can be less stable under deoxygenating conditions, this is not the primary issue.

 Option B. Function pertains to the ability of hemoglobin to carry oxygen. HbS can still carry oxygen, but the sickling process can hinder its release to tissues.

Option C. Affinity refers to the hemoglobin's ability to bind oxygen. HbS has a slightly different oxygen affinity compared to normal hemoglobin, but again, this is not the main problem.

Educational Objective:

Sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) is primarily characterized by reduced solubility under deoxygenated conditions, leading to polymerization and sickling of red blood cells. This results in vaso-occlusive crises and chronic hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 638

choices.text: Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis
Binding of lead to transferrin, inhibiting the trans­port of iron
Binding of lead to cell membrane of erythroid pre­cursors.
Binding of lead to ferritin inhibiting their break­down into hemosiderin

questions.text: The pathogenesis of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme bio­synthesis

Option A:

The pathogenesis of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning is primarily due to the inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis. Lead interferes with several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, including aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) and ferrochelatase. This interference leads to a decrease in the production of heme and, subsequently, hemoglobin.

Explanation:

Option B. Lead does not bind to transferrin directly

Option C. While lead can affect cell membranes, the primary mechanism of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning is related to its impact on enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis, not direct binding to cell membranes.

Option D. Lead does not directly bind to ferritin to inhibit their breakdown. The primary effect is on heme synthesis enzymes.

Educational Objective:

The primary pathogenesis of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning involves the inhibition of enzymes necessary for heme biosynthesis, such as aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) and ferrochelatase, leading to reduced heme and hemoglobin production.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 411, Tejinder Singh 1st/147

choices.text: Yellowing of eyes and sclera
Decrease in haptoglobin
Low reticulocyte count

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and dark urine. Laboratory tests reveal anemia with increased bilirubin levels. Which of the following laboratory findings is inconsistent with a diagnosis of hemolytic anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Low reticulocyte count

Option D:

Haemolytic anaemia is characterised by the increased reticulocyte count, splenomegaly (especially extravascular hemolysis) and increased concentration of bilirubin and urobilinogen

 A low reticulocyte count would be unusual in hemolytic anemia because the bone marrow typically responds to anemia by increasing production of reticulocytes, the immature red blood cells.

Explanation:

Option A. Yellowing of eyes and sclera is due to hyperbilirubinemia, which is commonly seen in hemolytic anemia as a result of increased breakdown of red blood cells.

Option B. Increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is often observed in hemolytic anemia because this intracellular enzyme is released into the blood when red cells are destroyed.

Option C. A decrease in haptoglobin is expected in hemolytic anemia. Haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin released from lysed red blood cells, and its levels drop as it is consumed in this process.

Educational Objective:

Hemolytic anemia is typically characterized by an increased reticulocyte count as the bone marrow compensates for the loss of red blood cells. A low reticulocyte count suggests an inadequate bone marrow response.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 634

choices.text: Beta thalassemia
Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: A 6-years-old child belonging to Punjabi family with past history of blood transfusions presented with hemoglobin 3.5 g/dl, MCV – 30 fl, MCHC – 20. Peripheral smear findings of microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cell and reduced osmotic fragility. What is the he probable diagnosis of patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Beta thalassemia

 

Option B:

Friends, let’s get the answer of this question in a methodical manner. The clues in the question:

Reduced values of MCV and MCHC: microcytic hypochromic anemia (G6PD deficiency is ruled out)

Age of presentation and ethnicity: 6-year-old and Punjabi ethnicity

History of repeated blood transfusion: in favour of thalassemia

Osmotic fragility is reduced: in favour of thalassemia again though it may be seen in sickle cell also

Also, the hemoglobin is the question is more suggestive of severe anemia with positive history of multiple blood transfusions both being important pointers towards thalassemia major. Other ethnic groups having high prevalence of thalassemia are Punajbis, Sindhis, Gujaratis, Parsis, Begalis and Lohanas.

The above-mentioned points point to thalassemia. Since beta thalassemia is more prevalent, it is a better option than alpha thalassemia.

Explanation:

Option A. Alpha thalassemia typically presents with microcytic anemia and can be severe depending on the number of gene deletions but is less common in the Punjabi population.

Option C. Sickle cell anemia usually presents with normocytic anemia and not typically microcytic anemia. It can have target cells but is most commonly associated with the African population.

Option D. G6PD deficiency can lead to hemolytic anemia, often episodic and related to oxidative stress, but it typically does not cause a microcytic hypochromic anemia or a reduced MCV and MCHC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The  presentation of severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, a history of multiple blood transfusions, and reduced osmotic fragility in a child from an ethnicity with a high prevalence of thalassemia strongly suggests beta thalassemia major as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with fatiguability and dyspnea on exertion. She was found to be having a hemoglobin of 6 g/dL. What will be most likely finding in her peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Microcytic and hypochromic red cells

 

Option D:

 

Microcytosis (smaller than normal red cells) and hypochromia are classic findings in iron deficiency anemia, which is consistent with the patient's symptoms and low hemoglobin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Macrocytosis (larger than normal red cells) typically indicates a deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate, not iron. While hypochromia refers to red cells with reduced hemoglobin content, it is not typically associated with macrocytosis.

 

Option B. Target cells can be seen in various hemoglobinopathies, liver disease, and post-splenectomy, but they are not characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Poikilocytosis refers to abnormally shaped red blood cells and is a nonspecific finding. The term "reduced poikilocytosis" is not typically used to describe findings in anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a patient with anemia, particularly in the setting of fatigue and dyspnea on exertion with a significantly low hemoglobin level, finding microcytic and hypochromic red cells on the peripheral blood smear strongly suggests iron deficiency anemia.

choices.text: Anemia of chronic disease
Iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is evaluated for anemia. Laboratory findings reveal increased serum ferritin, decreased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), increased serum iron, and elevated transferrin saturation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sideroblastic anemia 

Option B:

Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by increased serum ferritin levels, decreased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC), increased serum iron, and an elevated percentage saturation of transferrin.

Sideroblastic anemia - Characterized by ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow, this condition leads to ineffective iron utilization, causing increased serum ferritin, decreased TIBC, increased serum iron, and elevated transferrin saturation.

Explanation:

Option A. Anemia of chronic disease- Typically presents with normal to increased serum ferritin, normal to decreased serum iron, and low transferrin saturation due to the sequestration of iron in macrophages.

Option C. Iron deficiency anemia - Manifests with decreased serum ferritin, increased TIBC, decreased serum iron, and low transferrin saturation due to a lack of iron stores.

Option D. Thalassemia minor - This condition usually presents with normal iron studies and is characterized by microcytic red blood cells without an increase in iron parameters.

Educational Objective:

Sideroblastic anemia is indicated by increased serum ferritin, decreased TIBC, increased serum iron, and elevated transferrin saturation, reflecting a defect in the incorporation of iron into hemoglobin within the erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.

questions.text: All of the following if present provide protection against malaria except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Duffy blood group

 

Option A:

 

Conditions providing protection against malaria with the reasons

 

Absence of duffy blood group: duffy antigen is required for parasite to enter the RBCs

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sickle cell disease: P falciparum cannot multiply properly in the presence of HbS α and β thalassemia:

 

Option D. G6 PD deficiency: G6PD is required for respiration of plasmodium

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of the Duffy blood group, the trait for sickle cell disease, thalassemia traits, and G6PD deficiency are all known to confer some protection against malaria due to various mechanisms that interfere with the parasite's ability to infect or survive within red blood cells. However, the Duffy blood group's absence, while protective against Plasmodium vivax, does not provide protection against P. falciparum, the most common and virulent cause of malaria.

 

Summary:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 403

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient notices spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearly arranged nodules in different parts of the body. Which of the following malignancies is not associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bladder carcinoma

Option D:

The given clinical presentation is suggestive of migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) and it is not associated with bladder carcinoma.

While bladder carcinoma can be associated with a hypercoagulable state, it is less commonly linked to Trousseau syndrome compared to the adenocarcinomas of the pancreas, lung, and gastrointestinal or gynecologic malignancies.

Explanation:

Option A. Uterine carcinoma: Uterine carcinoma, particularly when adenocarcinoma, can be associated with Trousseau syndrome due to its propensity to induce a hypercoagulable state, leading to venous thromboembolism.

Option B. Pancreatic carcinoma: Pancreatic carcinoma is strongly associated with Trousseau syndrome. The tumor's release of mucins and procoagulant substances can trigger a hypercoagulable state.

Option C. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Bronchogenic carcinoma, especially adenocarcinoma subtype, is known to produce substances that activate the coagulation system, thus it can be associated with Trousseau syndrome.

Educational Objective:

Bladder carcinoma is not commonly associated with Trousseau syndrome, which is characterized by migratory thrombophlebitis and is often seen with deep-seated adenocarcinomas like those of the pancreas, lung, and other visceral organs.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 329

questions.text: An elderly female with mediastinal mass undergoes a microscopic examination showing red cell aplasia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymoma

Option B:

Direct lines from Ref: Robbins. “In addition to myasthenia gravis, thymomas may be associated with several other paraneoplastic syndromes. These include in rough order of frequency, pure red cell aplasia, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi organ autoimmunity”.

Thymomas are tumors originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus and can be associated with various paraneoplastic syndromes, including pure red cell aplasia. This is a condition where there is a selective decrease in red blood cell precursors in the bone marrow, leading to anemia.

Explanation:

Option A. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Bronchogenic carcinoma refers to a type of lung cancer originating from the bronchi. Although it can present with a mediastinal mass, it is not typically associated with pure red cell aplasia, which is a reduction in the production of red blood cells.

Option C. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a diverse group of blood malignancies that includes any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Types of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can involve the mediastinum but are not typically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma:  Squamous cell carcinoma can arise in various organs, including the lungs, but is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia or mediastinal masses unless it is metastatic from another primary location.

Educational Objective:

Thymomas are mediastinal tumors that may be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, including pure red cell aplasia, which is characterized by a selective decrease in red blood cell precursors.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p493

choices.text: Deletion of alpha genes
Deletion of beta genes
Excess of alpha genes
Single amino acid substitution in alpha chain

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of alpha thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deletion of alpha genes

Explanation:

Option A:

Deletion of alpha genes is the primary cause of alpha thalassemia. The number of deleted genes can affect the severity of the disease; the loss of two genes causes mild disease, while the loss of all four genes leads to hydrops fetalis.

Option B. Deletion of beta genes leads to beta thalassemia. This condition results from mutations in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11, not the alpha-globin gene on chromosome 16.

Option C. Excess of alpha genes does not cause alpha thalassemia. Typically, an imbalance between alpha and beta chains due to a relative lack of alpha genes is what causes thalassemias.

Option D. Single amino acid substitution in the alpha chain is commonly associated with hemoglobin variants like Hemoglobin C or S, but not with thalassemia, which is a quantitative problem with globin chain production.

Educational Objective:

Alpha thalassemia is most commonly caused by the deletion of alpha genes on chromosome 16, which leads to a quantitative reduction in the production of alpha-globin chains.

choices.text: Plasma homocysteine levels
Peripheral smear showing megaloblasts
High value of mean cell volume
Serum methylmalonic acid levels

questions.text: Which of the following test best differentiates cobalamin and folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Serum methylmalonic acid levels

Option D:

Serum methylmalonic acid levels are increased specifically in cobalamin deficiency because cobalamin is a cofactor for the conversion of methylmalonic acid to succinyl CoA. In folate deficiency, methylmalonic acid levels remain normal.

Explanation:

Option A. Plasma homocysteine levels are elevated in both cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate deficiencies, as both vitamins are involved in the metabolism of homocysteine. Therefore, it does not differentiate between the two.

Option B. Peripheral smear showing megaloblasts is a feature common to both cobalamin and folate deficiencies, as both lead to impaired DNA synthesis and resultant megaloblastic anemia.

Option C. A high mean cell volume (MCV) is indicative of macrocytic anemia, which can result from either cobalamin or folate deficiency. This finding is not specific to either condition.

Educational Objective:

Serum methylmalonic acid levels is one of diagnostic test that differentiates between cobalamin and folate deficiencies, since it is increased in cobalamin deficiency but remains normal in folate deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine health check-up. She has no complaints and her medical history is unremarkable. She undergoes a Pap smear as part of her cervical cancer screening. The cytology report describes disorganized growth of cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. Which of the following best characterizes the cellular changes seen in this patient's Pap smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysplasia

Option B:

Pap smear having disorganised growth of the cells with hyperchromatic nuclei is suggestive of dysplasia. Carcinoma is diagnosed when abnormal mitotic figures are discovered and is called invasive when basement membrane is affected.

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal growth and disorganization of cells, often with variations in size, shape, and orientation. The term is often used when referring to precancerous or potentially premalignant conditions. In a Pap smear, dysplastic cells with hyperchromatic (darkly staining) nuclei suggest a higher likelihood of progressing to cervical cancer, especially if abnormal mitotic figures are present.

Explanation:

Option A. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy refers to an increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the organ. It is usually seen in response to increased demand or stimulation by hormones or growth factors. Unlike hyperplasia, hypertrophy does not involve an increase in the number of cells. An example would be the increase in muscle mass due to exercise.

Option C. Metaplasia: Metaplasia is the reversible change from one type of cell to another due to abnormal stimulus, which can potentially predispose to malignancy if the stimulus persists. A classic example is Barrett’s esophagus, where the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus changes to a columnar epithelium in response to chronic gastric acid exposure.

Option D. Hyperplasia: Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue, which may subsequently increase the size of the organ or tissue. It is a response to a stimulus and is usually a controlled process. Hyperplasia can be a physiological response, such as the proliferation of glandular epithelium of the female breast at puberty or pathologic as seen in endometrial hyperplasia.

Educational Objective:

Dysplasia, is a term used to describe disorganized growth of cells with varying size, shape, and orientation, often with hyperchromatic nuclei, suggestive of a precancerous state.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p719-720

choices.text: Mucosal cell iron stores
Route of administration
Age of the patient

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is undergoing workup for fatigue and joint pain. His serum ferritin levels are markedly elevated, and a liver biopsy shows iron deposition. Which of the following most directly regulates iron uptake in the gut?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mucosal cell iron stores  

Option A:

Mucosal cell iron stores influence the synthesis of hepcidin, a peptide hormone that regulates iron uptake by inhibiting its transport across the gut mucosa. Increased iron stores lead to increased hepcidin levels, which decreases iron absorption.

Explanation:

Option B. The route of administration, such as oral or parenteral, can influence the rate of iron absorption but does not directly regulate iron uptake at the molecular level.

Option C. The preparation administered, for example, ferrous sulfate versus ferric gluconate, can affect the efficiency of absorption but, like the route, does not regulate the iron uptake process per se.

Option D. The age of the patient can affect the demand for iron, especially during growth spurts or aging, but it is not a direct regulator of iron uptake in the gut.

Educational Objective:

Mucosal cell iron stores, through their regulation of hepcidin synthesis, play a direct role in regulating iron uptake across the gut mucosa, which is crucial for maintaining systemic iron homeostasis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 658

questions.text: NESTROF test is a screening test for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. β- thalassemia

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

β-thalassemia - NESTROFT is used to screen for beta-thalassemia because red blood cells in this condition exhibit reduced fragility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

NESTROFT is a screening test for beta-thalassemia, which is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red blood cells in this condition.

 

The NESTROFT test (Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a simple, cheap screening test used especially in countries like India to screen for β-thalassemia trait (carrier state).

 

How it works:

 

  • Based on the principle that RBCs in thalassemia are microcytic and hypochromic → they have a reduced osmotic fragility (more resistant to lysis in hypotonic saline).
  • In the test:
    • A single hypotonic saline solution (usually around 0.36% NaCl) is used.
    • After incubation, if the solution remains turbid → positive test (RBCs did not lyse → likely β-thalassemia trait).
    • If the solution becomes clear → negative test (RBCs lysed → normal).

choices.text: Aberrant expression of a receptor tyrosine kinase
An inborn defect in DNA repair

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is referred to a dermatologist for several "suspicious" pigmented lesions on his face and neck. Further history reveals the patient has had problems seeing out of his right eye; he is referred to an ophthalmologist, who diagnoses ocular melanoma. Based on the patient’s symptoms, the diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum is considered. This condition results from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) An inborn defect in DNA repair

Option B:

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a hereditary DNA defect with a deficiency in the ability to repair ultraviolet (sunlight)-induced thymine dimers. Faulty repair leads to increased sun sensitivity, with a predilection to develop skin lesions and skin cancers on exposed skin, as well as ocular melanomas.

Explanation:

Option A.  Aberrant expression of the gene for a receptor tyrosine kinase, such as the Her-2/neu gene product, can cause breast cancer.

Option C. Chemical carcinogens have highly reactive electrophile groups that directly damage DNA, leading to mutations and eventually cancer.

Option D.  A retrovirus is responsible for the development of T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Educational Objective:

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a condition resulting from a hereditary deficiency in the nucleotide excision repair pathway, leading to an inability to repair UV-induced thymine dimers, with resultant increased skin and ocular malignancies.

questions.text:
Which of the following are oncofetal antigens?

 

  1. Alpha-fetoprotein
  2. Carcinoembryonic antigen
  3. Human chorionic gonadotropin
  4. Placental alkaline phosphatase
  5. Immunoglobulins
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are oncofetal antigens.

 

Alpha-fetoprotein is a valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of the following tumors:

 

  • Primary hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratomas
  • Choriocarcinoma

 

Carcinoembryonic antigen is normally detected in the glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells. It is useful in detection, assessing recurrence, and prognosis of the following tumors:

 

  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Colorectal carcinoma

 

CEA levels >5 g/dL are noted in ascitic fluid associated with malignancy.

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin: Not an oncofetal antigen; it is a placental hormone, elevated in choriocarcinoma, testicular tumors.

 

Placental alkaline phosphatase: A placental enzyme, considered a tumor-associated antigen, but not truly oncofetal.

 

Immunoglobulins: These are normal adult proteins; elevated in plasma cell dyscrasias (e.g., multiple myeloma), but not oncofetal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-fetoprotein and carcinoembryonic antigen are oncofetal antigens, which are expressed during fetal development and re-expressed in certain malignancies, aiding in the diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of these cancers.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 336

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with loss of weight and appetite. On clinical examination, grade IV clubbing is evident. Imaging shows periosteal new bone formation and left knee joint effusion. Which of the following tumors is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bronchogenic carcinoma

Option A:

The given clinical history is suggestive of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. It is commonly associated with bronchogenic carcinoma.

Bronchogenic carcinoma, particularly non-small cell lung cancer, is the most common cause of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, which is characterized by periosteal new bone formation, arthritis of adjacent joints, and clubbing.

Explanation:

Option B. Carcinoma of the pancreas: While patients with pancreatic cancer may develop paraneoplastic syndromes, hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is not typically associated with this type of malignancy.

Option C. Esophageal carcinoma:  Esophageal carcinoma can be associated with paraneoplastic phenomena including clubbing, but it is less commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy compared to bronchogenic carcinoma.

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia: Hematologic malignancies like AML are not commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. Paraneoplastic syndromes are more commonly associated with solid tumors.

Educational Objective:

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is characterized by the following:

  • Periosteal new bone formation, primarily at the distal ends of long bones, metatarsals, metacarpals, and proximal phalanges
  • Arthritis of the adjacent joints
  • Clubbing of the digits

choices.text: Presence of testicular involvement at presentation
Presence of blasts in peripheral smear

questions.text: Which of the following is having poor prognosis in ALL?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Presence of testicular involvement at presenta­tion

 

Option C:

 

(Presence of testicular involvement at presentation): Testicular involvement at presentation is considered an adverse prognostic factor in ALL. It suggests extramedullary disease, which can be associated with a higher risk of relapse and may require more intensive treatment, including radiotherapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: (TLC 4000-10000): Total leukocyte count (TLC) at presentation is an important prognostic factor in ALL. Normal or moderately elevated TLCs are generally associated with a better prognosis. A very high TLC, particularly above 100,000, is typically considered a poor prognostic indicator in ALL, particularly in T-cell ALL.

 

Option B: (Age between 1-10 years): age less than 1 year or more than 10 years has poor prognosis.

 

Option D: (Presence of blasts in peripheral smear): The presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear is characteristic of ALL but on its own is not necessarily a poor prognostic indicator. The percentage and the total number of blasts can provide more specific prognostic information, with a higher burden sometimes indicating more aggressive disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of testicular involvement at presentation in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is associated with a poorer prognosis due to the risk of extramedullary relapse and the need for more aggressive treatment.

 

Poor Prognostic Factors in ALL:

 

  • Age < 1 or > 10 years
  • TLC > 50,000/µL
  • CNS or testicular involvement
  • Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL)
  • Poor response to induction therapy
  • Hypodiploidy

choices.text: Acute blood loss

questions.text: A patient has been eating junk food regularly for few months and avoids fruits and vegetables. His hemoglobin is 9 g/dl and MCV is >125 fl. What is the deficiency she would likely be having?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Folate deficiency

Option B:

Folate deficiency can develop quickly with poor dietary habits and leads to megaloblastic anemia, which presents with a high MCV. Given the patient's diet devoid of fruits and vegetables, this is a probable cause.

Explanation:

Option A. Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency typically develops over years due to the substantial stores in the liver. While it can cause megaloblastic anemia with a high MCV, the patient's short history of symptoms makes this less likely.

Option C. Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by the presence of ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow and can be associated with certain drugs and toxins, genetic disorders, or may be idiopathic. It doesn't typically relate directly to dietary habits and usually shows a normal or increased MCV but not typically in the megaloblastic range (>100 fL).

Option D. Acute blood loss would cause anemia with a low or normal MCV (microcytic or normocytic), not the high MCV (>100 fL) that is typical of megaloblastic anemias. Plus, there is no history suggestive of blood loss.

Educational Objective:

Folate deficiency is the likely cause of megaloblastic anemia with a high MCV in a patient with a diet lacking in fruits and vegetables and a relatively quick onset of symptoms, as folate stores are depleted much more rapidly than vitamin B12 stores.
